questions.q: What does 'AI' stand for?
options: Automated Internet
Artificial Intelligence
Advanced Integration
Algorithmic Interface
questions.explanation: AI stands for Artificial Intelligence — systems designed to perform tasks that typically require human intelligence.

questions.q: Which of these is an example of an AI chatbot?
options: Microsoft Excel
Google Maps
ChatGPT
Adobe Photoshop
questions.explanation: ChatGPT is an AI chatbot built by OpenAI. Excel, Maps, and Photoshop are software tools but not AI chatbots.

questions.q: What is a 'prompt' in AI?
options: A warning message from the computer
The text or question you type to communicate with AI
The AI's internal programming code
A timer that counts down before AI responds
questions.explanation: A prompt is the text, question, or instruction you provide to an AI system to get a response.

questions.q: AI chatbots generate responses by:
options: Searching the internet in real-time for every answer
Predicting likely text based on patterns learned during training
Copying and pasting from a database of pre-written answers
Connecting to a human operator who types the response
questions.explanation: AI chatbots use pattern recognition from their training data to predict and generate the most likely next words in a response.

questions.q: Which of these tasks can AI help with?
options: Writing and editing text
Physical activities like cooking
Making moral decisions for you
Guaranteeing 100% correct answers
questions.explanation: AI excels at text-based tasks like writing and editing. It cannot perform physical activities, make moral decisions, or guarantee perfect accuracy.

questions.q: What should you always do after receiving an AI response?
options: Accept it immediately as fact
Share it on social media right away
Review it and verify important claims
Delete it and start over
questions.explanation: Always review and verify AI outputs, especially factual claims. AI can generate plausible-sounding but incorrect information.

questions.q: AI is called 'artificial' because:
options: It is fake and cannot do anything useful
It is created by humans, not a natural form of intelligence
It always gives artificial or made-up answers
It only works on artificial or virtual things
questions.explanation: The term 'artificial' means human-made — AI is intelligence created by humans through engineering, not a naturally occurring phenomenon.

questions.q: What is one thing AI cannot do?
options: Summarize a long article
Translate text between languages
Truly understand emotions and feelings
Generate creative writing ideas
questions.explanation: While AI can simulate emotional language, it does not truly understand or experience emotions and feelings the way humans do.

questions.q: The best way to start using AI is to:
options: Memorize all available AI commands first
Start with a simple question and see how it responds
Read the entire AI documentation before trying anything
Only use it for complex professional tasks
questions.explanation: The best approach is to start simple — ask a basic question, observe the response, and gradually build your skills from there.

questions.q: Why do different AI chatbots sometimes give different answers to the same question?
options: Some chatbots are broken and give wrong answers
They were trained on different data and have different designs
Only one chatbot can be correct at a time
The internet connection affects the quality of answers
questions.explanation: Different AI models are trained on different datasets with different architectures and design choices, leading to variation in their outputs.

questions.q: What does 'LLM' stand for?
options: Large Language Model
Logical Learning Machine
Linear Logic Module
Live Learning Mechanism
questions.explanation: LLM stands for Large Language Model — AI systems trained on massive amounts of text data to understand and generate human language.

questions.q: Which company created ChatGPT?
options: Google
Microsoft
OpenAI
Apple
questions.explanation: ChatGPT was created by OpenAI, an AI research company. Microsoft is an investor in OpenAI but did not build ChatGPT.

questions.q: What is the main purpose of a chatbot?
options: To replace human workers entirely
To have text-based conversations and assist users
To store personal data for companies
To browse the internet faster
questions.explanation: Chatbots are designed to have text-based conversations with users, answering questions and providing assistance on various topics.

questions.q: AI learns from:
options: Its own personal experiences
Large amounts of data provided during training
Watching YouTube videos in real-time
Reading users' minds
questions.explanation: AI models learn patterns from large datasets provided during their training process — they do not have personal experiences or real-time learning from the internet.

questions.q: What is 'machine learning'?
options: Teaching machines to physically move
A type of AI where systems learn patterns from data
A manual for operating computers
Software that learns to type faster
questions.explanation: Machine learning is a subset of AI where systems automatically learn and improve from data patterns without being explicitly programmed for every scenario.

questions.q: Which of these is NOT an AI chatbot?
options: ChatGPT
Claude
Gemini
PowerPoint
questions.explanation: PowerPoint is a presentation software tool. ChatGPT (OpenAI), Claude (Anthropic), and Gemini (Google) are all AI chatbots.

questions.q: What happens when you close an AI chat session?
options: The AI remembers everything for next time
The conversation is typically not carried over to new sessions
The AI gets smarter from your conversation
Your data is permanently deleted from the internet
questions.explanation: Most AI chatbots do not retain conversation history between separate sessions unless specifically designed to do so with memory features.

questions.q: AI can help you with writing by:
options: Automatically publishing your work online
Suggesting improvements, drafting text, and checking grammar
Guaranteeing your writing will go viral
Replacing the need to learn writing skills
questions.explanation: AI can assist with drafting, editing, grammar checking, and suggesting improvements — but it works best as a writing aid, not a replacement for writing skills.

questions.q: What does it mean when people say AI can 'hallucinate'?
options: The AI sees visual images like humans do
The AI generates confident but incorrect information
The AI stops working temporarily
The AI becomes self-aware
questions.explanation: AI hallucination refers to when the model generates information that sounds plausible and confident but is actually incorrect or fabricated.

questions.q: Which is the safest way to use AI-generated information?
options: Copy and paste it directly into your work
Use it as a starting point and verify the facts
Assume it is always correct
Only use it if it agrees with your opinion
questions.explanation: AI output should be treated as a starting point — always verify facts, check sources, and use your own judgment before relying on the information.

questions.q: What is 'natural language processing' (NLP)?
options: A way for computers to understand human language
A technique for speaking more naturally
A programming language used to build websites
A method for processing food naturally
questions.explanation: Natural Language Processing (NLP) is a branch of AI focused on enabling computers to understand, interpret, and generate human language.

questions.q: When you ask AI a question, the response is:
options: Always 100% factually accurate
Generated based on patterns, not guaranteed to be correct
Copied directly from a specific website
Reviewed by a human before being sent to you
questions.explanation: AI responses are generated based on statistical patterns learned during training — they are not fact-checked or guaranteed to be accurate.

questions.q: Which of these is a benefit of using AI?
options: It eliminates the need for human thinking
It can help automate repetitive tasks quickly
It always provides the cheapest solution
It never makes mistakes
questions.explanation: One of AI's greatest benefits is automating repetitive tasks efficiently, freeing up human time for more creative and complex work.

questions.q: What is a 'chatbot'?
options: A robot that can walk and talk
A software program that simulates conversation
A person who chats online professionally
A device that records phone calls
questions.explanation: A chatbot is a software program designed to simulate conversation with human users, typically through text-based interfaces.

questions.q: AI-generated text is created by:
options: A team of writers working behind the scenes
Statistical prediction of what words come next
Searching Wikipedia for every answer
Recording and replaying human conversations
questions.explanation: AI generates text by statistically predicting the most likely next word in a sequence, based on patterns learned from its training data.

questions.q: What should you NOT share with an AI chatbot?
options: A recipe you want to improve
Your passwords and sensitive personal information
A school essay topic you need help with
A book recommendation request
questions.explanation: Never share passwords, financial details, or sensitive personal information with AI chatbots — treat them as public conversations.

questions.q: The 'training data' for an AI model is:
options: The questions users ask after the model is released
The large collection of text the model learned from
The instructions manual that comes with the software
The electricity used to power the AI servers
questions.explanation: Training data is the massive collection of text, books, articles, and other content that an AI model processes during its learning phase.

questions.q: Which company created the Claude AI assistant?
options: Google
Anthropic
Meta
Amazon
questions.explanation: Claude was created by Anthropic, an AI safety company focused on building reliable and safe AI systems.

questions.q: AI is best described as:
options: A conscious being that thinks like humans
A tool that processes information using learned patterns
A replacement for all human jobs
A perfect source of information
questions.explanation: AI is a tool that processes information using patterns learned from data — it is not conscious, not a job replacement for all roles, and not infallible.

questions.q: What does 'generative AI' mean?
options: AI that generates electricity
AI that can create new content like text, images, or code
AI that only analyzes existing data without creating anything
AI that generates revenue for companies automatically
questions.explanation: Generative AI refers to AI systems that can create new content — including text, images, music, and code — rather than just analyzing existing data.

questions.q: When using AI to help with homework, you should:
options: Submit the AI's response as your own work
Use it to understand concepts, then write in your own words
Tell the AI to write at a student's level to avoid detection
Never use AI for any educational purpose
questions.explanation: AI is best used as a learning aid — use it to understand concepts and get explanations, then express your understanding in your own words.

questions.q: What is a 'language model'?
options: A diagram showing how languages are related
An AI system trained to understand and generate human language
A translation dictionary for foreign languages
A set of grammar rules for proper writing
questions.explanation: A language model is an AI system trained on large amounts of text to understand and generate human language based on statistical patterns.

questions.q: AI chatbots are limited because they:
options: Can only respond in English
Do not have real-world experiences or senses
Can only answer yes or no questions
Require an internet connection to think
questions.explanation: AI chatbots lack real-world experiences, physical senses, and genuine understanding — they work with patterns in text, not lived experience.

questions.q: What does 'output' mean in the context of AI?
options: The electricity the AI computer uses
The response or content the AI generates
The data the AI was trained on
The question the user types in
questions.explanation: In AI, 'output' refers to the response, text, image, or other content that the AI generates in response to a user's input.

questions.q: What does 'input' mean when talking about AI?
options: The AI's answer to your question
The information or text you provide to the AI
The AI's internal calculations
The speed of the AI's response
questions.explanation: Input is the information, text, question, or instruction that a user provides to an AI system to process and respond to.

questions.q: Which of these is an example of AI in everyday life?
options: A regular calculator app
Spam filters in your email
A physical paper dictionary
A wired telephone
questions.explanation: Email spam filters use AI and machine learning to identify and filter unwanted messages — a common everyday application of AI technology.

questions.q: What is the 'knowledge cutoff' of an AI model?
options: The maximum number of questions it can answer per day
The date after which the AI has no training data
The point where the AI stops learning from your conversation
The limit on how long its responses can be
questions.explanation: A knowledge cutoff is the date beyond which the AI model has no training data — it cannot know about events that happened after this date.

questions.q: If you ask an AI about a very recent news event, it might:
options: Search the news in real-time to find the answer
Not have information about it due to its training cutoff
Refuse to answer because news topics are restricted
Always give an accurate and current response
questions.explanation: AI models have a training data cutoff date, so they may not have information about events that occurred after that date.

questions.q: What is 'text generation' in AI?
options: Scanning paper documents into digital text
The AI creating new written content word by word
Converting speech to text using a microphone
Typing text faster using keyboard shortcuts
questions.explanation: Text generation is the process where an AI creates new written content by predicting and producing words sequentially based on the given input.

questions.q: Asking a vague question to AI will typically result in:
options: A more creative and interesting response
A generic or unhelpful answer
The AI asking for clarification every time
A faster response time
questions.explanation: Vague questions typically produce generic, unfocused responses because the AI has to guess what you actually need without clear direction.

questions.q: What makes a good question to ask AI?
options: It should be as short as possible
It should be specific and clearly state what you need
It should use complex technical language
It should contain multiple unrelated questions
questions.explanation: Good AI questions are specific, clearly state what you need, and provide enough context for the AI to generate a relevant, useful response.

questions.q: AI image generators create pictures by:
options: Downloading and combining existing photos from the internet
Learning visual patterns from training data and generating new images
Having human artists draw images behind the scenes
Taking screenshots from movies and TV shows
questions.explanation: AI image generators learn patterns from large datasets of images during training, then generate entirely new images based on text descriptions.

questions.q: What is 'deep learning'?
options: Studying AI topics very thoroughly
A type of machine learning using layered neural networks
Learning that happens while you sleep
AI that searches deep into the internet
questions.explanation: Deep learning is a type of machine learning that uses artificial neural networks with multiple layers to learn complex patterns from data.

questions.q: Which of the following is true about AI?
options: AI is always right
AI can think and feel like a human
AI is a tool that has limitations
AI will replace all jobs soon
questions.explanation: AI is a powerful tool with real limitations — it can make mistakes, lacks consciousness, and works best when used alongside human judgment.

questions.q: What is a 'neural network' in simple terms?
options: A social media network for AI researchers
A computer system inspired by the human brain's structure
The internet cables connecting AI servers
A network of security cameras using AI
questions.explanation: A neural network is a computing system loosely inspired by the structure of the human brain, using interconnected nodes to process information.

questions.q: If an AI gives you medical advice, you should:
options: Follow it immediately since AI has medical knowledge
Consult a real healthcare professional instead
Trust it only for minor health issues
Share it with friends as reliable information
questions.explanation: AI is not a licensed medical professional. Always consult a qualified healthcare provider for medical advice — AI can generate plausible but dangerous misinformation.

questions.q: What does 'conversational AI' mean?
options: AI that can only have formal business conversations
AI systems designed to engage in human-like dialogue
A conference call tool powered by AI
AI that converts conversations to text documents
questions.explanation: Conversational AI refers to systems specifically designed to engage in human-like dialogue, understanding context and generating natural responses.

questions.q: The more specific your prompt is, the more likely AI will:
options: Take longer to respond
Give you a useful and relevant answer
Get confused by too much information
Charge you more for the response
questions.explanation: Specific prompts help the AI understand exactly what you need, leading to more focused, relevant, and useful responses.

questions.q: Which of these is a risk of relying too heavily on AI?
options: Becoming more creative
Losing critical thinking and verification habits
Learning too many new things
Having too much free time
questions.explanation: Over-reliance on AI can erode critical thinking skills and the habit of verifying information — it is important to maintain independent judgment.

questions.q: What is a 'token' in AI language models?
options: A coin used to pay for AI services
A small unit of text (word or word fragment) the AI processes
A security badge for accessing AI systems
A reward the AI gets for correct answers
questions.explanation: In AI, a token is a small unit of text — often a word, part of a word, or punctuation mark — that the language model processes and generates.

questions.q: AI voice assistants like Siri use:
options: Pre-recorded responses for every possible question
Speech recognition and natural language processing
Human operators who speak the responses
Simple keyword matching without any AI
questions.explanation: AI voice assistants use speech recognition to understand spoken words and natural language processing to interpret meaning and generate responses.

questions.q: What is 'bias' in AI?
options: The AI's personal preference for certain topics
Unfair patterns in output reflecting imbalances in training data
A technical error that causes the AI to crash
The direction the text flows on screen
questions.explanation: AI bias occurs when the model produces unfair or skewed outputs because of imbalances, stereotypes, or gaps in its training data.

questions.q: Which is an example of AI being used in healthcare?
options: A doctor writing prescriptions by hand
AI analyzing medical images to help detect diseases
A patient reading a health article online
A hospital using paper medical records
questions.explanation: AI is used in healthcare to analyze medical images like X-rays and MRIs, helping doctors detect diseases earlier and more accurately.

questions.q: What does 'training' an AI model mean?
options: Teaching the AI to follow voice commands
Feeding the AI large amounts of data so it learns patterns
Installing the AI software on a computer
Having humans manually write every possible response
questions.explanation: Training an AI model means processing large datasets through the model so it learns statistical patterns and relationships in the data.

questions.q: AI-powered recommendation systems are used by:
options: Only scientific research institutions
Streaming services like Netflix and Spotify
Only government agencies
Traditional radio stations exclusively
questions.explanation: Streaming services like Netflix and Spotify use AI recommendation systems to suggest content based on your viewing and listening patterns.

questions.q: What is 'automation' in the context of AI?
options: Making cars drive themselves
Using AI to perform tasks without continuous human intervention
Automatically deleting old files from your computer
The AI turning itself on and off
questions.explanation: Automation refers to using AI and technology to perform tasks with minimal or no continuous human intervention, increasing efficiency.

questions.q: When AI makes a mistake, it is usually because:
options: It is trying to trick you on purpose
Its training data or the prompt was insufficient
It gets tired after too many questions
Someone hacked into the AI system
questions.explanation: AI mistakes typically stem from limitations in training data, ambiguous prompts, or the model extrapolating beyond its reliable knowledge.

questions.q: What is 'speech-to-text' technology?
options: Reading text aloud using a computer voice
Converting spoken words into written text using AI
Sending voice messages instead of typing
A phone feature that makes calls using text commands
questions.explanation: Speech-to-text (also called speech recognition) uses AI to convert spoken language into written text, enabling voice-based input for devices.

questions.q: What is 'text-to-speech' technology?
options: Typing faster using voice commands
AI converting written text into spoken audio
A texting app that also supports phone calls
Recording your voice to create a text file
questions.explanation: Text-to-speech uses AI to convert written text into natural-sounding spoken audio, used in accessibility tools, navigation, and virtual assistants.

questions.q: Which is the best description of how AI 'thinks'?
options: It has a brain like humans but made of silicon
It processes mathematical calculations on data patterns
It daydreams and comes up with creative ideas
It connects to a hive mind of other AIs
questions.explanation: AI does not truly 'think' — it processes mathematical calculations and statistical patterns in data to generate outputs that appear intelligent.

questions.q: What is 'autocomplete' powered by?
options: A dictionary of every possible sentence
AI predicting what you are likely to type next
A human reviewing your text in real-time
Your keyboard memorizing your favorite phrases
questions.explanation: Autocomplete features use AI to predict the most likely next word or phrase based on context and patterns from language data.

questions.q: If you want AI to explain something simply, you should:
options: Use complicated language so the AI tries harder
Ask it to explain as if you were a beginner
Avoid giving any instructions about complexity level
Ask multiple complex questions at once
questions.explanation: Telling the AI your knowledge level (e.g., 'explain like I am a beginner') helps it adjust its language and complexity to match your needs.

questions.q: What does 'AI ethics' refer to?
options: Rules about how much AI can charge for services
Guidelines for the responsible and fair development and use of AI
The AI's personal moral compass and beliefs
Legal restrictions that ban AI in certain countries
questions.explanation: AI ethics refers to the principles and guidelines for developing and using AI responsibly, addressing fairness, transparency, privacy, and potential harms.

questions.q: What is a 'dataset' in AI?
options: A type of computer hardware for AI
A collection of data used to train or evaluate AI models
The settings you configure before using AI
A backup copy of the AI's memory
questions.explanation: A dataset is a structured collection of data — such as text, images, or numbers — used to train, test, or evaluate an AI model.

questions.q: Why is it important that AI is transparent?
options: So users can see the AI's source code
So people understand how AI makes decisions and can trust it appropriately
So competitors can copy the AI's design
So the AI can be invisible when not in use
questions.explanation: AI transparency helps users understand how decisions are made, enabling appropriate trust, accountability, and the ability to identify errors or bias.

questions.q: What is 'computer vision' in AI?
options: A computer screen with better display quality
AI that can analyze and understand images and video
A camera that connects to the internet
Software for creating visual presentations
questions.explanation: Computer vision is a field of AI that trains computers to interpret and understand visual information from images, videos, and the real world.

questions.q: AI translation tools work by:
options: Hiring bilingual humans to translate in real-time
Learning language patterns from millions of translated texts
Looking up every word in a digital dictionary one by one
Only translating between English and one other language
questions.explanation: AI translation tools learn patterns from vast amounts of translated text pairs, enabling them to translate meaning, not just individual words.

questions.q: What is an AI 'model'?
options: A physical robot that looks like a human
A trained system that can make predictions or generate content
A diagram showing how AI companies are organized
A simplified version of the internet
questions.explanation: An AI model is a trained system — essentially a mathematical representation — that can process inputs and generate predictions or content.

questions.q: Why might AI give a wrong answer even with a clear question?
options: The AI is being lazy and not trying hard enough
Its training data may contain errors or gaps on that topic
Clear questions are harder for AI to process
The AI intentionally gives wrong answers sometimes
questions.explanation: Even with clear prompts, AI can give incorrect answers due to gaps, errors, or biases in its training data, or because the topic requires very current information.

questions.q: What is a good first step if an AI response seems wrong?
options: Immediately report the AI as broken
Check the information against a reliable source
Accept it because AI is usually right
Ask the same question again without changing anything
questions.explanation: If an AI response seems wrong, the best first step is to verify the information against a reliable source like an official website, textbook, or expert.

questions.q: What is 'supervised learning' in simple terms?
options: AI that only works when a human is watching
Training AI with labeled examples so it learns the correct answers
A teacher supervising students who use AI
AI that monitors security cameras
questions.explanation: Supervised learning trains AI using labeled examples — data paired with correct answers — so the model learns to make accurate predictions on new data.

questions.q: An AI chatbot cannot:
options: Write poetry or creative stories
Help brainstorm ideas for a project
Access your personal files on your computer
Summarize a long article you paste into the chat
questions.explanation: Standard AI chatbots cannot access your personal files, computer, or local data — they can only process what you directly share in the conversation.

questions.q: What does 'context window' mean in AI?
options: The physical screen size needed to use AI
The amount of text an AI can consider at one time
A window that shows the AI's current mood
The time limit for each AI conversation
questions.explanation: The context window is the maximum amount of text (measured in tokens) that an AI model can process and consider at one time during a conversation.

questions.q: AI is often compared to a very skilled:
options: Doctor who can treat any illness
Pattern-matching and prediction engine
Mind reader who knows your thoughts
Time traveler who sees the future
questions.explanation: AI is fundamentally a pattern-matching and prediction engine — it identifies patterns in data and uses them to generate likely outputs.

questions.q: What is 'data privacy' in the context of AI?
options: Keeping AI models secret from the public
Protecting personal information from being misused by AI systems
Making AI data run faster on private networks
Hiding AI error messages from users
questions.explanation: Data privacy in AI refers to protecting personal information from being collected, stored, or used inappropriately by AI systems and the companies behind them.

questions.q: When AI is described as 'general purpose,' it means:
options: It can only do one thing but does it well
It can handle a wide range of different tasks
It is free for everyone to use
It works on all devices without installation
questions.explanation: A general-purpose AI can handle a wide range of tasks — from writing to analysis to coding — rather than being specialized for a single function.

questions.q: What is 'predictive text' on your phone?
options: Text messages that predict the future
AI suggesting words as you type based on patterns
A feature that reads your texts before you send them
Automatic spell-checking without AI
questions.explanation: Predictive text uses AI to suggest the next word as you type, based on language patterns and your personal typing history.

questions.q: What is 'facial recognition' technology?
options: A camera filter that adds effects to your face
AI that identifies or verifies people by analyzing their facial features
A mirror that tells you how you look today
Software that draws faces for art projects
questions.explanation: Facial recognition uses AI to identify or verify people by analyzing and comparing their facial features against stored data.

questions.q: Why should you not blindly trust AI for legal advice?
options: AI charges too much for legal advice
AI is not a licensed professional and may give incorrect legal information
Legal topics are blocked by AI safety filters
AI only knows laws from one country
questions.explanation: AI is not a licensed legal professional and can generate incorrect or outdated legal information — always consult a qualified attorney for legal matters.

questions.q: What does 'AI-powered' mean when describing a product?
options: The product runs on solar or wind energy
The product uses artificial intelligence to enhance its features
The product was designed by an AI without human help
The product is more expensive because of AI marketing
questions.explanation: AI-powered means the product incorporates artificial intelligence to improve its features, performance, or user experience.

questions.q: The 'context' you give an AI helps it:
options: Process your request faster
Understand your situation and give a more relevant response
Connect to additional databases for better answers
Remember your previous conversations
questions.explanation: Context gives the AI background information about your situation, enabling it to tailor its response to your specific needs and circumstances.

questions.q: What does 'iteration' mean when working with AI?
options: Using AI only once and accepting the result
Refining your approach through repeated attempts
Switching between different AI platforms
Letting the AI iterate through its own databases
questions.explanation: Iteration means refining your prompts and approach through repeated attempts, gradually improving the AI's output to match your needs.

questions.q: AI can be used to help people with disabilities by:
options: Replacing the need for human caregivers entirely
Providing tools like screen readers, speech recognition, and captioning
Only assisting with physical disabilities, not cognitive ones
Diagnosing disabilities more accurately than doctors
questions.explanation: AI enhances accessibility through tools like screen readers, real-time captioning, speech-to-text, and other assistive technologies for various disabilities.

questions.q: What is a 'virtual assistant'?
options: A human assistant who works remotely from home
An AI program that helps users perform tasks through voice or text
A video game character that gives you tips
An online receptionist at a doctor's office
questions.explanation: A virtual assistant is an AI-powered program — like Siri, Alexa, or Google Assistant — that helps users perform tasks through voice or text commands.

questions.q: What is the difference between AI and regular software?
options: There is no real difference
AI can learn from data and adapt, regular software follows fixed instructions
Regular software is more powerful than AI
AI only runs on special computers
questions.explanation: Traditional software follows fixed, pre-programmed instructions, while AI can learn patterns from data and adapt its behavior without explicit programming.

questions.q: If AI generates a paragraph with a confident tone, it means:
options: The information is definitely accurate
The AI is certain about its answer
The tone does not guarantee accuracy — always verify
A human reviewed and approved the response
questions.explanation: A confident tone in AI output does not indicate accuracy — AI can sound very confident while stating completely incorrect information.

questions.q: What is 'sentiment analysis' in AI?
options: The AI developing its own emotions
AI determining whether text expresses positive, negative, or neutral feelings
A mental health assessment performed by AI
The AI analyzing how sentimental a movie is
questions.explanation: Sentiment analysis uses AI to determine the emotional tone of text — identifying whether the expressed opinion is positive, negative, or neutral.

questions.q: Why is AI sometimes called a 'black box'?
options: Because AI servers are housed in black containers
Because it can be hard to understand how AI reaches its conclusions
Because AI only works in dark mode interfaces
Because the first AI was built in a black box
questions.explanation: AI is called a 'black box' because the internal decision-making process can be difficult to understand or explain, even for its creators.

questions.q: What is 'image recognition' in AI?
options: AI generating new images from text descriptions
AI identifying objects, people, or scenes in photos
Saving images in a format AI can read
A camera that automatically takes photos using AI
questions.explanation: Image recognition is an AI capability that identifies and classifies objects, people, scenes, or other elements within images and photographs.

questions.q: Responsible AI use includes:
options: Using AI for every task without question
Verifying outputs, respecting privacy, and acknowledging AI use
Keeping your AI use secret from others
Only using free AI tools to avoid bias
questions.explanation: Responsible AI use means verifying outputs for accuracy, protecting privacy, acknowledging when AI is used, and being aware of its limitations.

questions.q: What is a 'chatbot interface'?
options: The hardware that runs the chatbot
The visual design where you type messages and see responses
The chatbot's personality settings
A translation layer between different AI models
questions.explanation: A chatbot interface is the visual area — typically a text box and message display — where users type messages and view the AI's responses.

questions.q: AI is most useful when you:
options: Use it to make all your decisions for you
Treat it as one tool among many in your toolkit
Depend on it completely and stop thinking critically
Only use it for entertainment purposes
questions.explanation: AI is most valuable when used as one tool among many — combining it with your own knowledge, judgment, and other resources produces the best results.

questions.q: What is 'personalization' in AI?
options: Giving the AI a human name and personality
AI tailoring its responses or recommendations based on user preferences
The user personalizing the AI's appearance settings
Making the AI pretend to be a specific person
questions.explanation: AI personalization means the system tailors its outputs, recommendations, or behavior based on individual user preferences, behavior patterns, or stated needs.

questions.q: What does 'scalable' mean in AI technology?
options: The AI can change its physical size
The AI system can handle growing amounts of work or users
The AI can be weighed on a scale for measurement
The AI can only work at one fixed capacity
questions.explanation: Scalable means the AI system can handle increasing amounts of work, data, or users without requiring a complete redesign.

questions.q: What is 'spam detection' an example of?
options: Human email reviewers reading every message
AI classifying messages as wanted or unwanted
A physical filter on your internet router
A setting that deletes all emails automatically
questions.explanation: Spam detection uses AI classification to analyze incoming messages and determine whether they are legitimate or unwanted spam.

questions.q: What is 'cloud computing' and how does it relate to AI?
options: AI that only works when it is cloudy outside
Remote servers that provide the computing power AI needs
Storing AI programs on USB drives in the cloud
A weather prediction system powered by AI
questions.explanation: Cloud computing provides remote servers with powerful hardware that AI systems need for training and running models — most AI tools run in the cloud.

questions.q: When AI 'summarizes' a document, it:
options: Deletes the original document and keeps only key points
Identifies and presents the main ideas in a shorter form
Reads the document aloud to save you time
Translates the document into simpler English
questions.explanation: AI summarization identifies the most important ideas and information in a text and presents them in a concise, shorter form.

questions.q: What is an 'algorithm'?
options: A type of AI that plays music
A step-by-step set of instructions for solving a problem
The brand name of a popular AI tool
A mathematical error in AI calculations
questions.explanation: An algorithm is a step-by-step set of instructions or rules designed to solve a specific problem or perform a specific task.

questions.q: Why do AI companies update their models regularly?
options: To charge users more money for upgrades
To improve accuracy, fix issues, and add new capabilities
Because old models expire and stop working
To make the AI look different visually
questions.explanation: AI companies update models to improve accuracy, reduce errors, expand capabilities, and address newly discovered biases or safety concerns.

questions.q: The best mindset for using AI is:
options: Fear — AI is dangerous and should be avoided
Blind trust — AI knows best about everything
Critical curiosity — explore AI's capabilities while questioning its outputs
Indifference — AI is just a passing trend
questions.explanation: The healthiest approach to AI is critical curiosity — actively exploring what AI can do while maintaining a questioning, verification-oriented mindset.
